reviewText:
Chaser is honestly one of the most innovative games of the past, present, and future generation. After playing over 100 hours of this game, it's obvious where the inspiration for Bungie's Halo: Combat Evolved came from. Sure, it came out two years after Halo, but that's because they only saw Jo Wood's amazing design. If the investors had given him his $17.26 before, Chaser could've revolutionized gameplay for PC and would've put the Xbox and PS2 out of business.

My favorite part of the game is how the enemies just run into the wall in such a beautiful way. Sure, some might call it a glitch, but I know that was there by design. When Jo Wood presented the concept for Chaser to his two cats and a parrot (RIP Jo Wood the Parrot), he wasn't just imagining another game, he was imagining the future!

By far the most interesting character is Thruster Man. (SPOILER ALERT) Thruster man is a deep and well thought out character that I know Jo Wood put hours into creation. His one goal is to appear for 30 seconds, shoot at you 3 times, then continue off into the sunset. You (John Chaser) must help him out by shooting him, otherwise he'll keep going, never to actually come back and do his one job, which is to kill you. The chemistry between him and John Chaser is one for the ages. I will be sure to tell my kids about Thruster Man when I grow up.

Overall, I recommend this game, and look wish Jo Wood luck with his new developer team, Homeless Studios.

reviewText:
Chaser is about as generic as an FPS can get. It even has a useless pseudo bullettime mode.

You start off the game as John Chaser wakes up in some sort of cryogenic chamber on a space station with no idea who he is or why there is a small army destroying the space station in a rather over the top attempt to locate you.

You are immediately thrown in the action as the mindless hordes of enemies start attacking you from all sides as you make your way off the space station, through streets and sewers and even through a rather peculiar mini-submarine segment. It all feels very familiar though, it's all the same generic shooting you have seen before with nothing to set it apart.

The weapons all feel like plastic, the enemy AI is about as worthless as a blind guide dog and the maps are made entirely out of black and grey boxes.

The story is some of the most unbelievable manure you will ever encounter, not because it's surprising but because John Chaser appears to have no willpower whatsoever. Despite not know who he is, and everybody else seemingly knowing, he never bothers to ask. He also lacks the capacity to say no even when warned repeatedly not to go into the service of a particular sociopath.

All in all, this is one of those you can actually play twice without realizing it because it is all so generic and forgettable. Nothing stands out and nothing has been given that extra effort.

reviewText:
Been really undecided on what to think of this game, since it has some good aspects and some not so good. In general, it's not a bad FPS game. If you like single player FPS games, you might like it, but it's a very average shooter in every sense, and a lot of the time it may also feel rather unpolished, so I can't really recommend it.

One thing that is commendable is that it has an actual story, something that FPS games normally lack, but the story is spaced out by overly long and repetitive linear levels, in many of which you only have a couple of weapons to use, and the same kind of enemy, so you keep ploughing through dozens of the same enemies in the same corridors. The progression through the levels also feels the same all the time. If you say come across 4 doors in the area, I bet you anything 3 will be locked and 1 is open for you to go through. And on a few occasions when every door is locked, means you just gotta find a good old vent.

The game also never really autosaves during the levels and there are no checkpoints. So if you've forgotten to save for a while and die for some silly reason, like falling off a ladder, then you'll lose a lot of progress. My very first death was in the first level, getting crushed by the sliding double doors. I've no idea who would build the doors to actually do that, rather than, you know, sliding back open again if someone is passing through.

The enemies always seem to be aware of your presence before you even know they're there. They'll spot you for miles and across the other end of a large map. Sure, it adds to the challenge, but it's also kinda cheap and annoying. If I am being shot at, I'd prefer to be able to see who is doing that without needing to squint my eyes.

I had to leave the game on a sniping section, which is equivalent to an escort mission, except you're sitting in a lighthouse and have to cover your allies in a truck that's trying to make it through a military base with enemies shooting at it from everywhere. Not sure if I'd be willing to continue anymore.

Not a bad game, but feels very rough around the edges and has a mediocre gameplay. I was only really liking the story. This game could've been better off as a first person RPG, akin to Deus Ex, in my opinion.

reviewText:
I don't think I've found myself saying how bad a game is so often as while I was playing Chaser. Chaser is a run and gun FPS that is overly ambitious, and falls hard in just about every possible gaming aspect. I want to say it feels like a cross between Serious Sam and Red Faction, but to put this title in the same sentence as those other two is blasphemous.

There are just so many bad things to rip on: The graphics are decent for a 2003 release although they could have probably toned down on the shiny, over-glossed textures. The shooter aspects are bearable and the story is kind of reasonable, albeit extremely disjointed and severely lacking any depth due to the main character's case of amnesia. Voice acting is respectable, although the character graphics make for a stiff delivery.

If one thing stood out it's that Chaser is god awful too long. It took me over 15 hours to finish, but I'd say there's only 7-8 hours of real content here. All the excess fat is just mindless killing of never ending spawning AI in a maze of bland and boring visuals.

The AI just sucks, period. They spawn above you, below you, behind you and you never really know where they are until you are taking damage. Toward the end of the game, the AI difficulty ramped up exponentially literally requiring me to quick save after each kill which reminds me, there's no auto save here so save early and save often. There has to be at least 1,000 grunts that are trying to kill you and there's not a whole lot of variety in the bad guys.

The multitude of hidden passages and usable objects made it a chore just finding where you need to go next or what to do--no waypoints here. Some passages you even have to keep jumping until you get lucky enough to move on. But be careful because one wrong jump and you might end up getting your character stuck in that invisible crevice. Good thing you quick saved it just a moment ago right?

Too many useless guns. Most of them lacked effective damage, especially the grenade attachments. Five grenades to kill one guy--really? Yet the enemy grenades are a one shot kill on me.

I'm not even sure why I continued to press forward and complete it. I guess it was just a mind numbing case of hoping the next chapter would bring some clarity. In the end, I was left pretty much as clueless as when I first started.

I'm going to go sulk in a corner for a while and reflect on the nonsense I just played. In the meantime may I recommend to you either Red Faction or Serious Sam instead of this garbage.

reviewText:
I'll start this review of by informing people that there is a slo-mo like ability mapped to the caps lock key by default. As far as I know (unless I skipped it somehow) the game doesn't actually inform you of this and I only found out by pure chance when I spazzed on my keyboard trying to get away from an explosion...so yeah there's that.

Anywho as far as the game itself goes although I'm giving it a recomendation it is a real mixed bag game design wise. This is probably a game you'll have a love/hate relationship with. Overall the gunplay is great. I really enjoyed the old school twitch based no iron sights shooting and good old fashioned health and armour drops. It's the level design that really starts to let this game down in the last few hours. The first level has you going through a space station with very linier corridors with very little room for deviation whereas the next few levels open up a little more. About halfway through the game the levels start becoming a little too open, with unessessary doors and corridors becoming accessible and some just plain huge open spaces with zero guidence or indication where to go next. This is bearable though and it's not until the last few hours that it just gets tedious. The game starts resorting to horrible half-life like platforming (crouch jump and all) and extremely obscure and hidden paths like barely visible vents and holes in the ground. The end mission is definitelly the lowest point of the game unfortunately. There's also a terrible stealth mission very early in the game but thankfully it's the only one and is over reletively quickly.

If you're looking for a game with a cohesive story I would look elsewhere as well. The plot is all over the place and the cutscenes and voice acting are laughable. It's a shame because the game takes you to some amazingly different locations like a space station, gang infested city slums, Russian bases crawling with soldiers and even eventually to Mars for the 'big' conclusion. The amazing variety of weapons is fantastic and they all handle differently making each of them very situational.

So in conclusion, if you're looking for an old fashioned shooter with some fun gunplay I would say pick this up. Even if you don't play it all the way through to the boring conclusion (honestly the story ain't worth it) it's still a lot of fun.

This game is truly a masterpiece.

The voice acting is incredible and it's so amazing that the developers had to cut it off half way through the game, or else we would reach a state of nirvana and wouldn't be able to complete the game.

When I was younger I remember having the demo-version of this game, which featured the Little-Tokyo and the following underground level and playing it over and over again. Maybe that's the reason I like this game so much.

Anyways - Chaser is a true old school first person shooter. Long levels in which you might even get lost in your first playthrough but even though it's a shooter you will have lots of different experiences in this game.
Some examples - you flee from a space station, fight your way through mafia goons, defend a truck from incoming enemies and even have a long underwater level in which you have to fend off sentry u-boats while navigating through boat wrecks.
There's also a very big range of your weapon arsenal that changes throughout the game.
And, even though its from 2004, the graphics are still pretty good (if you turn your resolution up enough).
Aside from shooting itself you have a Adrenaline-slow motion function that you can use against your enemies.
Another important aspect of the game is the story about the Protagonist John Chaser and his amnesia, which is carried on by cutscenes and dialogues throughout the game.
I give this game 9/10 because it was one of the first real shooters I owned and I'm never getting tired of the plain but awesome shooting mechanics in this game.

People who searched for this game do not need to read reviews as are they have probably already played the game more than a decade ago and were driven here by nostalgia or some exciting memories about it.

Others, who see this for the first time, should bare few things in mind - if you never heard of logitech MX series of gaming mice, or how to use F6 quicksave button, maybe this is not a game for you. In this game there is no regenerating health, no automatic cover, and no rushing through the level. Crosshair doesn't take half of the screen and you can't play it with the controller. It's all about skill and precise aiming. Most enemies fall after one precise headshot and good aim and reflex is far more important than how full is your armor or health bar. The gameplay feeling is almost like that of good old Counter Strike or Rainbow Six. In short this is more of a tactical shooter - Call of Duty fans should just skip it.

On the other hand, if you are familiar with this type of games, you will be treated with very satisfying gameplay and you won't have too much problem going through levels. Graphics stand through test of time and game runs pretty well on modern systems. The storyline reminds of Total Recall, but can get pretty nonsense at times, and Mr. Chaser's choices are sometimes like those of 4 year lobotomized child. However the levels and  gameplay just gets better the more you play it.

Warmly recommended for oldschool gamers, especially considering price of few bucks!

reviewText:
Chaser, a classic FPS from 2003.

The CloakNT engine remains one of my favorites, as I love its scalability, looks, feel, and editing tools. Cauldron pulled off some interesting effects in the engine like dynamically lit particle effects, tesselated water surface that reacts to gunfire impacts, hybrid static/dynamic lighting and shadowing, realistic glass/wood breakables engine, environmental effects (environment impacts scope ring [fog, ice, dirt, etc], emissives from bullet impacts (shoot pipes or pressured glass windows), etc. A lot of these things are absent entirely from modern games/engines. It is a sad testament to the negative impact of console gaming.

The engine also is capable of rendering very large areas with long viewsheds with minimal performance cost. They did some really awesome things behind the scenes in the CloakNT engine, which is made even more impressive by the fact that the engine was created in-house from the ground up.

Combat is pure oldschool and twitchy; good stuff.

Music is superb, visual style is great (if inconsistent), and levels sprawl! They're huge, if sometimes a bit lacking in interactivity.

I love the variety of environments you find in this game, as well as the various play mechanics you'll use along the way.

Story is a cliche made of tropes and other cliches, but it works to good effect.

Main voice actor sounds like John Wayne. What isn't to like?

Multiplayer is fun and quick, a nice mix of Q3A and CS IF you can find a low-ping server. Lag compensation is ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• at best and anything above about 100ms you'll start to have lots of wtf moments.

There are a few cheaters unfortunately, but a good game can be had most of the time.

Do yourself a favor and get it for the massive singleplayer alone (20+hours)

reviewText:
This game feels like it was a bunch of lost potential. In fact, I had some fun with this one, and I figure with a little more polish it could have been remembered as a classic. However, there are two really big problems that prevent me from reccomending (or finishing) this... two problems that suck the life out of what could otherwise have been a decent shooter.

1) Bad Level Desgin:
In this game, YOU WILL BACKTRACK A LOT. For every path forward there are twenty dead ends... and most offer no reward whatsoever for exploration.

In a linear, story-driven game, this is an extreme indictment! Huge chunks of gameplay waste the players time and only bring boredom and frustration.

But there are also little problems to level desgin as well... things you would not normally think about until they go wrong. I will use an example from this game:
There is this level with a HUGE arena where a battle takes place. That is fine and well. But after the battle I ended up spending nearly 15 minutes searching for the way forward. There was this pile of rubble you are suppsed to climb up  and then a ladder above that. However, THE LADDER'S TEXTURE BLENDED INTO THE WALL TEXTURE. I ended up climbing that rubble no less than four times trying to get out of the arena and it was only on the fourth that I saw, just barely, that damned ladder.

Linear story-driven games, especially, cannot afford this kind of BS.

2) General Shooting Brokenness:
The second major problem involves a lot of minor issues with the shooting itself, but which add up to make a mediocure shooter downright frustrating. I will simply list them out:
-Enemies often point towards you and are ready to shoot at you before they have line of sight. Not only does this not make sense, but it also give them an unfair advatage.
-Enemies, thier weapons, AND THE PLAYER can clip through walls and doors, leading to many a BS damage (and the occational getting stuck).
-When one enemy knows of you... all do (think about the point at the top and see what problems that causes).
-Lack of varety. Enemies almost always consist of the same type (man with machine gun) with minor variations (now man has sniper).
-Samey corridor shooting. Rather than challenge the player with novel situations and varied, complementary ememies... 90% of gameplay is walking down a corridor and shooting the samey enemies.
-The game seems to depend on random health and armour pickups from enemies to sustain the player. Given how rapidly 100 health can go to 27 (which in most cases is as little as two shots from death) this turns certain portions of the game into peekaboo nightmares.
-Finally, there are rare enemies (man with genade launcher) which can one-hit-KO you. This is OK in shooters provided there is enough warning and enough chance to dodge. In Chaser... you get no such chance and have to simply eat a couple of deaths.

Fix the p i s s-poor level degisn and tweak the shooting? And you have something fun I would argue. But alas, Chaser has these problems, and I cannot reccomend it.

reviewText:
Chaser is a horribly buggy semi-competent budget shooter. There are only two good things about it; the guns and the music. The story and voice acting are so bad it's painful, and good gunplay dosen't excuse many deaths that felt cheap. Additionally, I've become stuck in various objects that lay directly in my path, forcing me to reload from a past save. On multiple occasions I 've encountered horrible graphical glitches that made the game completely unplayable (see my screen shots for this game if your curious). Anything unrealted to shooting, such as a biref stealth section, is so poorly designed that I have to wonder why it's in the game at all.

The gunplay itself is a lot of fun. There are several guns, and all behave more or less effectively. There is usually only 1 or 2 good weapons that you'll find yourself using throughout a level however, so there really isn't much point in the decent array you have to choose from.

The terrible enemy AI is compensated for with a reduced ability for the player to take damage and a high level of accuracy on the part of the AI. Any single enemy can kill you if you arn't careful, and there are a lot of enemies, but the enemies themselves die so quickly that getting through a level without using the time-slowing feature is a completely viable option, provided you have good reflexes for whenever the enemies start popping out from behind corners. The time slowing feature itself is hugely dissappointing, as it recharges too slowly to be any fun.

I've seen estimates of length that go up to 50 hrs of playtime and higher. I'm over half-way through the game at 5 hrs. Excluding deaths, I doubt this experience is longer than 8 hrs.
Lots of people love this game, and while the shooting is good, the stealth section and an underwater section where I literally CAN'T SEE have me wondering why.

reviewText:
Let me set the scene for you.

It's 2004 and I had a factory built desktop from Dell ($500 then). It was in no way built for gaming, but I was determined to play on it anyway.

I browsed the net for games to play for free, and I found a multiplayer demo of Chaser. I downloaded it, waited several hours for it to load, and installed it.

For being the first ever fullscreen multiplayer FPS I have ever played, this game was incredible. It was like Call of Duty to me as with kids today. I played every. Single. Day. From what I remember the multiplayer being like, it was fast paced, VERY strategic, had amazing level design, and a wonderful array of weapons to choose from. Every time I see a FAMAS-designed rifle in any other game, I am instantly reminded of Chaser. This game even taught me how to type at 80/wpm. I still often set my keybinds in other games according to Chaser's default keymapping.

Now, I know you're probably thinking, Well this is a review from memories of a 9 year old kid. Of course it's going to be over-exaggerated." Well

I have played through this game at least 4 or 5 times now, so clearly I think the game is good and worth playing and a buy.

I tend to like simple/budget FPS games, so I might be a bit biased but many other have given this game a good review on Steam despite what the meta-critic score is.

I think this game serves as another good example of why you really shouldn't listen to reviews, and give games a try that you think might be good regardless of what critics or your friends say.

Things I like about this game:
Graphics and texture work are good for the time they were made
Characters, including the campy voice acting/story
Lighting, again for the time it was created, it is pretty good for a budget FPS
Gunplay and gameplay are pretty good
